ground_truth: As Pappy brushes by them, Junior wheedles, and Pappy slaps at the young man with his hat and waves it at the radio building as singers in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases get out of the second car. Tommy sits in the background, playing and singing a slow blues while the three convicts, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. He stretches out, and Pete swishes his coffee as he stares into the blaze, giving his coffee a thoughtful swish and murmuring. The three men tense up as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low ridge. Their point-of-view shows a lone barn with their car parked to one side surrounded by various police vehicles that have pulled up facing the barn. Armed men, their backs to us, train guns on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The man with the bullhorn continues, directing his comments at the distant barn, while the three convicts notice the sheriff who once again stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains. The three men shuffle down the dusty road, losing their drift as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which comes into view cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four, and as it speeds along, dollar bills snap and flutter out its windows. The car roars up to the three men as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to call through the passenger window as Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb in, the car squeals out, and the driver shoots a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then gropes inside his coat. The man stops withdrawing the gun and appraises his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, and Everett slides over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the car roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain on him, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: As Pop brushes by them, Junior cajoles, and Pop swats at the young man with his cap and waves it at the broadcast edifice as vocalists in sham hillbilly garb with assorted melodic instrument cases disembark from the second automobile. Tommy sits in the backdrop, playing and crooning a slow blues while the three prisoners, clutching coffee mugs, gaze into the blaze. He extends out, and Pete swirls his coffee as he stares into the flame, giving his coffee a contemplative swirl and murmuring. The three fellows tense up as Pete shovels soil onto the fire and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low embankment. Their point-of-view displays a solitary barn with their vehicle stationed to one side encircled by various patrol vehicles that have pulled up facing the barn. Armed men, their backs to us, aim firearms on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked autos. The man with the bullhorn continues, directing his remarks at the distant barn, while the three prisoners notice the sheriff who once again stands stoically next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains. The three fellows shuffle down the dusty route, losing their drift as all three turn, reacting to the noise of an approaching speeding car which arrives into view cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four, and as it races along, dollar notes snap and flutter out its panes. The automobile roars up to the three fellows as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike visage, leans over to call through the passenger window as Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar note out of the air, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering note out of the air. The three fellows climb in, the automobile squeals out, and the driver shoots a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then gropes inside his jacket. The man stops withdrawing the firearm and evaluates his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper notes fluttering inside the automobile. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, and Everett slides over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the automobile roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit autos gain on him, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: As the singers in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases get out of the second car, Junior is wheedled by them as he is brushed by Pappy, who slaps at the young man with his hat and waves it at the radio building. A slow blues is being played and sung by Tommy in the background while coffee cups are held by the three convicts who gaze into the fire. As he is stretched out, his coffee is swished by Pete as he stares into the blaze, murmuring while he gives his coffee a thoughtful swish. Dirt is shoveled onto the fire by Pete as the three men tense up, and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low ridge. Their point-of-view shows a lone barn surrounded by various police vehicles that have pulled up facing it, with their car parked to one side. Guns are trained on it by armed men, their backs to us, with some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The bullhorn is continued with by the man as he directs his comments at the distant barn while the sheriff is noticed once again by the three convicts as he stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains. The dusty road is shuffled down by the three men, their drift lost as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which corners on two wheels and comes into view. It is crashed back onto all four, and dollar bills are snapped and fluttered out its windows as it speeds along. The three men are roared up to by the car as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb, and it is screeched to a halt. A call is leaned over to make through the passenger window by the driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, as a fluttering dollar bill is plucked out of the air by Delmar, who looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb in, the car is squealed out, and a glance is shot up to the rearview mirror by the driver as the sirens grow louder, then he gropes inside his coat. The gun is stopped from being withdrawn by the man as he appraises his passengers while the paper currency fluttering inside the car is reacted to by Delmar. The door is opened, and the running board is stepped onto by him, while Everett is given a casual gesture, which startles him as Everett slides over. Now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, George Nelson has clamped one hand on the car roof and waves to Delmar with the other while he sends a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Wild firing is done by Nelson as he gains on the pursuit cars, and their fire is returned.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: As Pappy passes by, Junior wheedles, and Pappy swats him with his hat, gesturing at the radio building as singers in faux hillbilly outfits exit the second car. Tommy sits in the background, playing slow blues while the three convicts, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. Pete swishes his coffee thoughtfully, murmuring. The men tense as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire, and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a ridge. They see a barn with their car beside it, surrounded by police vehicles. Armed men, backs to us, aim guns at the barn, some taking cover. The man with the bullhorn directs comments at the barn, while the sheriff stands impassively, holding a bloodhound's leash. The three men shuffle down the road, reacting to a speeding car cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four, and dollar bills flutter from its windows. The car roars up to them, Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb, and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit, calls through the window as Delmar plucks a dollar bill from the air, examines it, and pops it. Delmar, like a child with soap bubbles, grabs another bill. The men climb in, the car squeals out, and the driver glances at the rearview mirror as sirens grow louder, then reaches inside his coat. He stops withdrawing the gun, appraising his passengers as Delmar reacts to the fluttering currency. He steps onto the running board, gestures to Everett, who slides over. George Nelson, outside and facing pursuit vehicles, waves to Delmar while firing bullets back at them. Nelson fires wildly as pursuit cars gain, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: As Pappy passes by, Junior wheedles, and Pappy swats him with his hat, gesturing at the radio building as singers in faux hillbilly outfits exit the second car. Tommy plays slow blues while the three convicts, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. Pete swishes his coffee, murmuring, and the men tense as he shovels dirt onto the fire. Delmar and Everett peek over a ridge, seeing a barn with their car surrounded by police vehicles. Armed men aim guns at the barn, some taking cover. The man with the bullhorn addresses the barn, while the sheriff stands with a bloodhound. The convicts shuffle down the road, reacting to a speeding car cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto four, and dollar bills flutter from its windows. The car stops, and the driver, a young man in a sharp suit, calls through the window. Delmar catches a dollar bill, examines it, and pops it. He grabs another bill as the three men climb in. The car speeds off, the driver glances in the mirror, and reaches inside his coat. He stops withdrawing a gun, appraising his passengers as Delmar reacts to the currency inside. Delmar steps onto the running board, gesturing to Everett, who slides over. George Nelson, outside and facing pursuit vehicles, waves to Delmar and fires bullets back at the pursuit cars, which return fire.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: As Pappy brushes by them with a brisk motion, Junior begins to wheedle, and Pappy responds by slapping at the young man with his hat, waving it dismissively in the direction of the radio building. Meanwhile, singers dressed in faux hillbilly outfits, each carrying various musical instrument cases, emerge from the second car. In the background, Tommy sits quietly, playing and singing a slow, soulful blues tune while the three convicts, each holding a steaming cup of coffee, gaze intently into the flickering fire. Tommy stretches out languidly, and Pete swishes his coffee thoughtfully, staring into the blaze with a contemplative expression, giving his coffee a deliberate swish and murmuring softly to himself. The three men suddenly tense up as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire, and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low ridge. From their vantage point, they see a lone barn with their car parked to one side, surrounded by an array of police vehicles that have pulled up, all facing the barn. Armed men, their backs turned to us, train their guns on the barn, some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The man with the bullhorn continues to speak, directing his comments at the distant barn, while the three convicts notice the sheriff, who once again stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains eagerly. The three men shuffle down the dusty road, losing their drift as all three turn in unison, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car that comes into view, cornering precariously on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four wheels, and as it speeds along, dollar bills snap and flutter out of its open windows. The car roars up to the three men, and Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb as it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man dressed in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to call through the passenger window. Delmar, meanwhile, plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, looks at it with wonder, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, and then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child mesmerized by soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb into the car, which squeals out with a burst of speed, and the driver shoots a quick glance up to the rearview mirror as the sound of sirens grows louder. He then gropes inside his coat, but stops withdrawing the gun, appraising his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, and Everett slides over, startled by the sudden movement. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped firmly on the car roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain on him, returning fire with equal intensity.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: As Pappy swiftly brushes past them with a rapid and brisk motion, Junior begins to wheedle in a somewhat coaxing manner, and Pappy responds by swatting at the young man with his hat, waving it in a dismissive and casual fashion in the general direction of the radio building. Meanwhile, a group of singers, all dressed in costumes reminiscent of faux hillbilly outfits, each burdened with various musical instrument cases, emerge from the second car in a lively manner. In the background, Tommy sits quietly and comfortably, playing and singing a slow, soulful blues tune that resonates deeply. Nearby, the three convicts, each clutching a steaming cup of coffee, gaze intently into the flickering flames of the campfire. Tommy stretches out languidly, and Pete gives his coffee an introspective swish, staring deeply into the fire with a contemplative expression, giving his coffee another deliberate swish while murmuring softly to himself. Suddenly, the three men tense up as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire, and with swift movements, Delmar and Everett scramble to peer over a low ridge. From their elevated vantage point, they can clearly see a solitary barn with their car parked off to one side, surrounded by an array of police vehicles which have pulled up, all facing towards the barn in an imposing line. Armed men, their backs turned away from us, train their guns on the barn, with some taking cover strategically on the near side of their parked cars. The man holding the bullhorn continues to speak, directing his comments in the direction of the distant barn, while the three convicts take notice of the sheriff, who once again stands impassively by the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which his bloodhound strains eagerly, eager to pursue. The three men shuffle down the dusty road, their attention momentarily diverted, as all three turn in unison to react to the sound of an approaching car speeding towards them, coming into view as it precariously corners on two wheels. It crashes back to balance on all four wheels, and as it rushes along, dollar bills snap and flutter out of its open windows like a chaotic cascade. The car roars up to the three men, and Delmar optimistically waggles a hopeful thumb as it screeches to a sudden halt. The driver of the car, a young man dressed in a sharp, well-tailored suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to call out through the passenger window. Meanwhile, Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, examining it with a sense of wonder and amazement, holding it stretched between both hands, bringing the two sides together, and then giving it an appraising pop. Like a child mesmerized by the delicate dance of floating soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the swirling currency and deftly yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb into the car, which takes off with a sudden burst of speed, and the driver quickly glances up at the rearview mirror as the sound of sirens grows ever louder. He then reaches inside his coat, but stops short of withdrawing the gun, appraising his passengers carefully as Delmar reacts with curiosity to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door and steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, prompting Everett to slide over, startled by the sudden movement. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped firmly on the car roof and waves cheerfully to Delmar with the other, all the while sending a relentless spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain ground on him, returning fire with equal intensity and determination.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Pappy brushes by them, Junior begins to wheedle, prompting Pappy to react by swiftly slapping at the young man with his hat, then energetically waving it in the direction of the radio building. Meanwhile, singers dressed in faux hillbilly outfits, each carrying various musical instrument cases, emerge from the second car. In the background, Tommy sits, absorbed in playing and singing a slow blues tune, while the three convicts, each holding a coffee cup, fix their gazes on the fire. He stretches out languidly, and Pete, with a contemplative air, swishes his coffee, staring deeply into the blaze, giving his coffee another thoughtful swish and murmuring softly. Suddenly, the three men tense up as Pete decisively shovels dirt onto the fire, prompting Delmar and Everett to scramble quickly to peek over a low ridge. From their vantage point, they see a lone barn with their car parked to one side, surrounded by various police vehicles that have pulled up, all facing the barn. Armed men, their backs turned to the observers, train their guns on the barn, with some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The man with the bullhorn continues his announcements, directing his comments at the distant barn, while the three convicts notice the sheriff standing impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains eagerly. The three men begin to shuffle down the dusty road, their pace slowing as they lose their drift, when all three suddenly turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car that comes into view, cornering precariously on two wheels. The car crashes back onto all four wheels and, as it speeds along, dollar bills snap and flutter out of its windows. The car roars up to the three men, and Delmar optimistically waggles a hopeful thumb, causing the car to screech to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to call through the passenger window, while Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, looks at it with wonder, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, and gives it an appraising pop. Like a child mesmerized by soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb into the car, which then squeals out, and the driver shoots a quick glance up to the rearview mirror as the sound of sirens grows louder. He then gropes inside his coat, but stops withdrawing the gun, taking a moment to appraise his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. Delmar opens his door, steps onto the running board, and gives Everett a casual gesture, prompting Everett to slide over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the car roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain on him, returning fire with equal intensity.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Pappy brushes by, Junior wheedles, prompting Pappy to slap at him with his hat and gesture toward the radio building, where singers in faux hillbilly outfits emerge from a car with musical instruments. Meanwhile, Tommy plays a slow blues in the background as the three convicts, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. Pete swishes his coffee thoughtfully and murmurs, then shovels dirt onto the fire, causing the men to tense up. Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a ridge, spotting a barn surrounded by police vehicles with armed men taking cover and aiming guns. The sheriff stands impassively with a bloodhound beside the man with the bullhorn, who directs comments at the barn. The convicts shuffle down the road, reacting to a speeding car that corners on two wheels, crashes back onto all four, and spews dollar bills from its windows. As the car roars up, Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb, and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit, calls through the window as Delmar plucks a dollar bill from the air, examines it, and pops it with satisfaction. Delmar, captivated by the floating currency, grabs another bill before the three men climb into the car. As the car speeds away, the driver glances in the rearview mirror, hears the growing sirens, and reaches inside his coat. He pauses, appraising his passengers, while Delmar reacts to the fluttering bills inside. The driver, George Nelson, steps onto the running board, gestures to Everett, who slides over, startled. Nelson, now outside, waves to Delmar and fires at the pursuit vehicles, which return fire as they close in.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: As Pappy brushes by them, a nickname likely derived from his grandfatherly demeanor, Junior wheedles, and Pappy slaps at the young man with his hat and waves it at the radio building, which is known locally for broadcasting popular country and western shows, as singers in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases get out of the second car. Tommy sits in the background, playing and singing a slow blues reminiscent of the Delta blues style, while the three convicts, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. He stretches out, and Pete swishes his coffee as he stares into the blaze, giving his coffee a thoughtful swish and murmuring. The three men tense up as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low ridge. Their point-of-view shows a lone barn, a common hideout in rural areas, with their car parked to one side surrounded by various police vehicles that have pulled up facing the barn. Armed men, part of a larger task force tracking fugitives, their backs to us, train guns on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The man with the bullhorn continues, directing his comments at the distant barn, while the three convicts notice the sheriff, a figure known for his relentless pursuit of outlaws, who once again stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains, a breed renowned for its tracking capabilities. The three men shuffle down the dusty road, losing their drift as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which comes into view cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four, and as it speeds along, dollar bills, likely the proceeds from a recent bank heist, snap and flutter out its windows. The car roars up to the three men as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb, hitchhiking in desperate hope, and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, turns out to be George Nelson, a notorious bank robber known for his erratic behavior, leans over to call through the passenger window as Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men climb in, the car squeals out, and the driver shoots a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then gropes inside his coat. The man stops withdrawing the gun, a weapon often associated with his criminal escapades, and appraises his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, and Everett slides over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the car roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson fires wildly, a hallmark of his reckless abandon, as the pursuit cars gain on him, returning fire.

The man with the bullhorn continues directing his comments at the distant barn while the three convicts notice the sheriff who once again stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains. The three men shuffle down the dusty road losing their drift as all three turn reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which comes into view cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four and as it speeds along dollar bills snap and flutter out its windows. The car roars up to the three men as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: As the giraffe brushes by them, the penguin wheedles, and the giraffe slaps at the young man with his hat and waves it at the radio building as lemurs in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases get out of the second car. The turtle sits in the background, playing and singing a slow blues while the three dolphins, holding coffee cups, gaze into the fire. The rabbit stretches out, and the lion swishes his coffee as he stares into the blaze, giving his coffee a thoughtful swish and murmuring. The three octopuses tense up as the lion shovels dirt onto the fire and the peacock and the kangaroo scramble to peek over a low ridge. Their point-of-view shows a lone barn with their car parked to one side surrounded by various submarine vehicles that have pulled up facing the barn. Armed moose, their backs to us, train guns on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars. The elephant with the bullhorn continues, directing his comments at the distant barn, while the three dolphins notice the giraffe who once again stands impassively next to the elephant with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a hedgehog strains. The three octopuses shuffle down the dusty road, losing their drift as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which comes into view cornering on two wheels. It crashes back onto all four, and as it speeds along, dollar bills snap and flutter out its windows. The car roars up to the three octopuses as the kangaroo waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt. The driver, a young owl in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to call through the passenger window as the kangaroo plucks a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, the kangaroo looks around at the wafting currency and yanks another fluttering bill out of the air. The three dolphins climb in, the car squeals out, and the owl shoots a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then gropes inside his coat. The owl stops withdrawing the gun and appraises his passengers as the kangaroo reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving the kangaroo a casual gesture, and the kangaroo slides over, startled. Nelson Mandela, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the car roof and waves to the kangaroo with the other while sending a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car. Mandela fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain on him, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: As Pappy brushes by them, Junior wheedles, and Pappy slaps at the young man with his scarf and waves it at the radio tower as dancers in faux urban outfits with various art supply cases get out of the second van. Tommy sits in the background, playing and singing a slow jazz while the three convicts, holding tea cups, gaze into the campfire. He stretches out, and Pete swishes his tea as he stares into the blaze, giving his tea a thoughtful swish and murmuring. The three men tense up as Pete shovels gravel onto the fire and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low fence. Their point-of-view shows a lone shed with their pickup parked to one side surrounded by various fire trucks that have pulled up facing the shed. Armed men, their backs to us, train water hoses on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked trucks. The man with the megaphone continues, directing his comments at the distant shed, while the three convicts notice the ranger who once again stands impassively next to the man with the megaphone, holding a chain against which a beagle strains. The three men shuffle down the rocky trail, losing their path as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding motorcycle which comes into view cornering on two tires. It crashes back onto all four, and as it speeds along, confetti snaps and flutters out its baskets. The motorcycle roars up to the three men as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt. The rider, a young man in a sharp jacket with a round, babylike face, leans over to call through the passenger basket as Delmar plucks a fluttering piece of confetti out of the air, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a child gazing at soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the wafting confetti and yanks another fluttering piece out of the air. The three men climb in, the motorcycle squeals out, and the rider shoots a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then gropes inside his coat. The man stops withdrawing the slingshot and appraises his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper confetti fluttering inside the motorcycle. He opens his door, steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual gesture, and Everett slides over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the motorcycle roof and waves to Delmar with the other while sending a spray of marbles back at the pursuit motorcycle. Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit motorcycles gain on him, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: As Pappy glides past them, Junior babbles, and Pappy flicks at the young man with his hat and aims it at the radio building as singers in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases shuffle out of the second car. Tommy reclines in the background, listening and humming a slow blues while the three convicts, holding coffee cups, squint into the fire. He curls up, and Pete twirls his coffee as he peers into the blaze, giving his coffee a thoughtful twirl and whispering. The three men tense up as Pete scatters leaves onto the fire and Delmar and Everett lurch to glance over a low ridge. Their point-of-view reveals a lone barn with their car parked to one side surrounded by various police vehicles that have rolled up facing the barn. Armed men, their backs to us, brandish guns on it, some ducking on the near side of their parked cars. The man with the bullhorn continues, projecting his comments at the distant barn, while the three convicts discern the sheriff who once again surveys impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash against which a bloodhound barks. The three men amble down the dusty road, losing their drift as all three pivot, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which bursts into view swerving on two wheels. It slides back onto all four, and as it speeds along, dollar bills tumble and glide out its windows. The car blares up to the three men as Delmar waves a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a stop. The driver, a young man in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, leans over to shout through the passenger window as Delmar snags a fluttering dollar bill out of the air, gazes at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two hands, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising flick. Like a child marveling at soap bubbles, Delmar scans around at the wafting currency and snaps another fluttering bill out of the air. The three men clamber in, the car skids out, and the driver darts a glance up to the rearview mirror as the sirens grow louder, then rummages inside his coat. The man pauses retrieving the gun and scrutinizes his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper currency fluttering inside the car. He opens his door, hops onto the running board, giving Everett a casual nod, and Everett inches over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand gripping the car roof and gestures to Delmar with the other while sending a stream of bullets back at the pursuit car. Nelson shoots erratically as the pursuit cars close in on him, firing back.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: As the mailbox brushes by them, the tomato wheedles, and the mailbox slaps at the kangaroo with its hat and waves it at the lighthouse as penguins in faux astronaut outfits with various tennis racket cases get out of the second train. The spatula sits in the background, playing and singing a slow tango while the three robots, holding teacups, gaze into the television. It stretches out, and the towel swishes its tea as it stares into the aquarium, giving its tea a thoughtful swish and murmuring. The three bicycles tense up as the towel shovels gravel onto the television and the lamp and the refrigerator scramble to peek over a low fence. Their point-of-view shows a lone helicopter with their skateboard parked to one side surrounded by various tricycle vehicles that have pulled up facing the helicopter. Armed pillows, their backs to us, train cameras on it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked desks. The potato with the trumpet continues, directing its comments at the distant helicopter, while the three bicycles notice the pumpkin who once again stands impassively next to the potato with the trumpet, holding a blanket against which a chameleon strains. The three bicycles shuffle down the dusty hallway, losing their drift as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding bicycle which comes into view cornering on two paws. It crashes back onto all four, and as it speeds along, postage stamps snap and flutter out its doors. The bicycle roars up to the three bicycles as the lamp waggles a hopeful antenna and it screeches to a halt. The toaster, a young pumpkin in a sharp uniform with a round, babylike nose, leans over to call through the passenger tunnel as the lamp plucks a fluttering postage stamp out of the sky, looks at it wonderingly, holds it stretched between two handles, brings the two sides together, then gives it an appraising pop. Like a kangaroo gazing at smoke rings, the lamp looks around at the wafting confetti and yanks another fluttering stamp out of the sky. The three bicycles climb in, the bicycle squeals out, and the toaster shoots a glance up to the rearview telescope as the gongs grow louder, then gropes inside its blanket. The pumpkin stops withdrawing the pizza slicer and appraises its passengers as the lamp reacts to the confetti fluttering inside the bicycle. It opens its tunnel, steps onto the running board, giving the refrigerator a casual gesture, and the refrigerator slides over, startled. The bread, now fully outside and facing the pursuit planes, has one hand clamped on the bicycle roof and waves to the lamp with the other while sending a spray of arrows back at the pursuit bicycle. The bread fires wildly as the pursuit bicycles gain on it, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: As Bessie dances by them, Marvin pleads, and Bessie pokes at the young girl with her boot and gestures it at the clock tower as dancers in faux pirate outfits with various musical instrument cases step out of the third van. Jerry stands in the background, drumming and humming a slow jazz while the four musicians, holding apple pies, gaze into the ocean. She bends back, and Carla swirls her apple pie as she glances into the tide, giving her pie a thoughtful swirl and musing. The four women tense up as Carla kicks sand onto the ocean and Gloria and Maureen scramble to peek over a tall hill. Their point-of-view shows a solitary lighthouse with their van parked to one side surrounded by various parade floats that have rolled up facing the lighthouse. Masked figures, their fronts to us, aim slingshots at it, some taking shelter on the far side of their parked floats. The lady with the megaphone continues, directing her monologue at the distant lighthouse, while the four musicians observe the captain who once again stands motionless next to the lady with the megaphone, holding a flashlight against which a greyhound strains. The four women waddle down the rocky path, losing their balance as all four turn, responding to the sound of an approaching flying helicopter which comes into view gliding on two wings. It lands softly onto all six, and as it hovers along, feathers snap and flutter out its doors. The helicopter zooms up to the four women as Gloria flutters a hopeful handkerchief and it lands to a stop. The pilot, an elderly woman in a colorful dress with a square, doll-like face, leans over to shout through the side window as Gloria snatches a fluttering feather out of the air, examines it curiously, holds it taut between two fingers, brings the tips together, then gives it an appraising tug. Like a squirrel gazing at falling leaves, Gloria glances around at the drifting feathers and grabs another fluttering one out of the air. The four women climb in, the helicopter lifts off, and the pilot casts a look back to the rearview monitor as the sirens grow softer, then fishes inside her pocket. The woman stops producing the flare and evaluates her passengers as Gloria reacts to the silky plumes fluttering inside the helicopter. She opens her window, steps onto the skid, giving Maureen a dismissive nod, and Maureen scoots over, confused. Linda Johnson, now completely outside and facing the rescue choppers, has one hand gripping the skid and waves to Gloria with the other while tossing a handful of confetti back at the rescue helicopter. Johnson throws wildly as the rescue choppers close in on her, returning streamers.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: As Pappy glides past them, Junior cajoles, and Pappy taps at the young man with his cap and signals it at the television studio as performers in imitation cowboy costumes with various travel luggage emerge from the second van. Tommy reclines in the background, sketching and humming a slow jazz while the three escapees, holding teapots, gaze into the pond. He expands out, and Pete twirls his tea as he stares into the ripple, giving his tea a thoughtful swirl and murmuring. The three men stiffen up as Pete scatters sand onto the pond and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a small hill. Their point-of-view shows a lone silo with their truck parked to one side surrounded by various fire trucks that have pulled up facing the silo. Armed men, their backs to us, point hoses at it, some taking cover on the near side of their parked trucks. The man with the megaphone continues, directing his remarks at the distant silo, while the three escapees notice the marshal who once again stands impassively next to the man with the megaphone, holding a chain against which a greyhound pulls. The three men amble down the sandy street, losing their stride as all three turn, reacting to the sound of an incoming racing motorcycle which comes into view leaning on two wheels. It bounces back onto all four, and as it zips along, receipts whirl and dance out its saddlebags. The motorcycle roars up to the three men as Delmar flicks a hopeful finger and it slides to a stop. The rider, a young man in a crisp tuxedo with a round, childlike face, leans over to call through the sidecar window as Delmar snatches a drifting receipt out of the air, examines it curiously, holds it stretched between two hands, folds the two sides together, then gives it an investigatory flick. Like a child watching soap bubbles, Delmar looks around at the drifting receipts and plucks another drifting slip out of the air. The three men climb in, the motorcycle screeches out, and the rider shoots a glance up to the side mirror as the horns grow louder, then fumbles inside his jacket. The man pauses extracting the flashlight and scrutinizes his passengers as Delmar reacts to the paper receipt fluttering inside the bike. He opens his door, steps onto the side step, offering Everett a laid-back gesture, and Everett shifts over, startled. George Nelson, now fully outside and facing the trailing vehicles, has one hand fixed on the bike roof and salutes Delmar with the other while unleashing a stream of paintballs back at the trailing bike. Nelson throws wildly as the trailing motorcycles gain on him, returning fire.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: As Granny saunters past them, Sonny cajoles, and Granny taps at the elder woman with her umbrella and points it at the bakery tower as dancers in fake urban attire with various painting brush holders hop out of the second bus. Jenny reclines in the background, sketching and humming a slow jazz while the three tourists, clutching teacups, stare into the fountain. She sprawls out, and Paula stirs her tea as she gazes into the cascade, giving her tea a pondering stir and muttering. The trio freezes up as Paula scoops sand onto the fountain and Molly and Oliver scurry to glance over a low mound. Their view reveals a lone cabin with their bus parked to one side surrounded by various fire trucks that have pulled up facing the cabin. Armed figures, their backs to us, aim hoses at it, some taking shelter on the near side of their parked buses. The woman with the megaphone continues, directing her remarks at the distant cabin, while the three tourists spot the ranger who once again stands stoically next to the woman with the megaphone, holding a chain against which a greyhound pulls. The trio trudges down the sandy path, losing their balance as all three pivot, responding to the noise of an approaching zooming train which slides into view cornering on one rail. It thumps back onto the tracks, and as it zooms on, feathers twirl and rustle out its windows. The train rushes up to the trio as Molly waves a curious hand and it screeches to a stop. The conductor, a young man in a crisp tuxedo with a round, kitten-like face, leans over to shout through the passenger window as Molly snags a fluttering feather out of the breeze, examines it curiously, holds it pinched between two fingers, brings the two ends together, then gives it a speculative snap. Like a toddler staring at soap suds, Molly glances around at the drifting plumage and snatches another twirling feather out of the breeze. The trio hops in, the train howls out, and the conductor flicks a look up to the rearview window as the alarms swell louder, then fumbles inside his pocket. The conductor halts retrieving the whistle and surveys his travelers as Molly responds to the drifting feathers swirling inside the train. She opens her window, steps onto the running step, giving Oliver a nonchalant wave, and Oliver shifts over, surprised. Gordon Wilson, now fully outside and facing the chase trains, has one hand gripped on the train roof and waves to Molly with the other while firing a cascade of arrows back at the chase train. Wilson shoots haphazardly as the chase trains close in on him, returning projectiles.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: As Pappy passes by, Junior tries to engage him, but Pappy dismissively waves his hat at a group of singers emerging from a car. Meanwhile, Tommy plays blues music as the three convicts, holding coffee, stare at the fire. Pete, lost in thought, swishes his coffee until the men become alert upon noticing police vehicles surrounding a barn near their parked car. Armed men aim guns at the barn, and the sheriff stands by with a bloodhound. Suddenly, a speeding car approaches, spewing dollar bills. Delmar catches one and examines it curiously. The car screeches to a halt, and a young, sharp-suited driver invites them in. The convicts hop in as sirens approach, and the driver, revealed as George Nelson, fires at the pursuing vehicles. Amidst the chaos, Delmar is captivated by the floating bills, while Nelson continues to shoot as the chase intensifies.

a spray of bullets back at the pursuit car  Nelson fires wildly as the pursuit cars gain on him returning fire As Pappy brushes by them Junior wheedles and Pappy slaps at the young man with his hat and waves it at the radio building as singers in faux hillbilly outfits with various musical instrument cases get out of the second car  Tommy sits in the background playing and singing a slow blues while the three convicts holding coffee cups gaze into the fire  He stretches out and Pete swishes his coffee as he stares into the blaze giving his coffee a thoughtful swish and murmuring  The three men tense up as Pete shovels dirt onto the fire and Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a low ridge  Their pointofview shows a lone barn with their car parked to one side surrounded by various police vehicles that have pulled up facing the barn  Armed men their backs to us train guns on it some taking cover on the near side of their parked cars  The man with the bullhorn continues directing his comments at the distant barn while the three convicts notice the sheriff who once again stands impassively next to the man with the bullhorn holding a leash against which a bloodhound strains  The three men shuffle down the dusty road losing their drift as all three turn reacting to the sound of an approaching speeding car which comes into view cornering on two wheels  It crashes back onto all four and as it speeds along dollar bills snap and flutter out its windows  The car roars up to the three men as Delmar waggles a hopeful thumb and it screeches to a halt
